facts.text: These petitions are under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the Contract Labour Regulation and Abolition Act, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C. J. These petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution challenge the validity of the Contract Labour  Regulation and Abolition  Act, 1970

facts.text: Petitioners carry on the business of contractors for construction of roads, buildings, weigh bridges and dams.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners carry on the business of companytractors for companystruction of roads, buildings, weigh bridges and dams.

facts.text: The Act requires contractors to take out licences.

anchor.surface_text: The Act requires companytractors to take out licences. The Act also imposes certain duties and liabilities on the companytractors.

facts.text: The Act defines contractor as a person who undertakes to produce a given result for the establishment through contract labour.

anchor.surface_text: The Act defines in section 2  c  a companytractor in relation to an establishment to mean a person who undertakes to produce a given result for the establishment, other than a mere supply of goods or articles of manufacture to such establishment, through companytract labour

facts.text: Petitioners contend they are not contractors within the definition of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytend that they are number companytractors- within the definition of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioners advance reason that their work is not part of the work of the principal employer.

anchor.surface_text: They advance two reasons. First, the work of the petitioners is number any part of the work of the principal employer number is it the work in companynection with the work of the establishment, namely, principal employer.

facts.text: Court holds petitioners are contractors within the meaning of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are companytractors within the meaning of the Act. The work which the petitioners undertake is the work of the establishment.

facts.text: The Act was passed to prevent the exploitation of contract labour and to introduce better conditions of work.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed to prevent the exploitation of companytract labour and also to introduce better companyditions of work.

facts.text: Bill was introduced in 1967 and passed in 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The bill was introduced in 1967. It was passed in 1970,

facts.text: Petitioners contend provisions of the Act are unconstitutional as unreasonable restriction under Article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention on behalf of the petitioners is that the provisions of the Act and the Rules made thereunder are unconstitutional. It is said that the application of the Act in respect of pending work of companystruction amounts to unreasonable restriction on the right of the companytractors under Article 19  1   g .

facts.text: Court holds there is no unreasonableness in the measure.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberunreasonableness in the measure.

facts.text: Fees for registration, licence prescribed do not amount to a tax.

anchor.surface_text: The fees prescribed for registration, licence and renewal of licences do number amount to a levy of tax.

facts.text: Petitioners contend provisions regarding canteens, rest rooms etc. are impracticable and unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners companytended that the provisions of the Act are unconstitutional and unreasonable because of impracticability of implementation. Provisions in regard to canteens, rest rooms,. latrines and urinals

facts.text: Court holds provisions for canteens etc. are reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The provision for canteen is number unreasonable. It is number impracticable to have a canteen.

facts.text: Petitioners contend section 14 regarding forfeiture of security is unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytended in the third place that the provisions companytained in section 14 of the Act with regard to forfeiture of security are unconstitutional.

facts.text: Court holds provisions regarding forfeiture do not suffer from constitutional infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act with regard to forfeiture do number suffer from any companystitutional infirmity.

facts.text: Section 34 of the Act does not amount to excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, section 34 of the Act does number amount to excessive delegation.

facts.text: Petitions are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the companytentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the petitioners are contractors within the definition of section 2(c) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contend that they are not contractors within the definition of the Act. They advance two reasons. First, the work of the petitioners is not any part of the work of the principal employer nor is it the work in connection with the work of the establishment, namely, principal employer.

issues.text: Whether the work undertaken by the petitioners constitutes 'work of the establishment' under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Second, the work of the petitioners is normally not done in the premises of the establishment of the principal employer. Relying on the definitions counsel for the petitioners contended that establishment means any place where any industry, trade, business, manufacture or occupation is carried on

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the Act and Rules impose unreasonable restrictions on the right of contractors under Article 19(1)(g), particularly for pending construction work

anchor.surface_text: The second contention on behalf of the petitioners is that the provisions of the Act and the Rules made thereunder are unconstitutional. It is said that the application of the Act in respect of pending work of construction amounts to unreasonable restriction on the right of the contractors under Article 19(1)(g).

issues.text: Whether the fees for registration, licence and renewal amount to a tax beyond rule-making powers

anchor.surface_text: The fees prescribed for registration, licence or renewal of licences are said to amount to a tax and are therefore beyond the rule-making powers of the Central and State Governments.

issues.text: Whether provisions for canteens, rest rooms, latrines etc. under sections 16, 17 and Rules are unreasonable and impracticable under Article 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: Provisions in regard to canteens, rest rooms, latrines and urinals as contemplated in sections 16 and 17 of the Act read with Central Rules 40 to 56 and Rule 25(2)(vi) are said to be incapable of implementation

issues.text: Whether section 14 of the Act regarding forfeiture of security is unconstitutional under Articles 14 and 19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contended in the third place that the provisions contained in section 14 of the Act with regard to forfeiture of security are unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether section 34 of the Act amounts to excessive delegation of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of the Act was challenged as unconstitutional. Section 34 of the Act provides that if any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of the Act, the Central Government may, by order, published in the official gazette,

issues.text: Whether section 28 of the Act confers arbitrary and unguided power violating Articles 14 and 19

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act was challenged as conferring arbitrary and unguided power and, therefore violative of Articles 14 and 19.

issues.text: Whether the Act violates Article 14 due to arbitrary classification or discrimination

anchor.surface_text: There is no violation of Article 14. The classification is not arbitrary. The legislature has made uniform laws for all contractors.

holdings.text: The petitioners are contractors within the meaning of the Act. The work which the petitioners undertake is the work of the establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioners is unsound. When the banking company employs the petitioners to construct a building the petitioners are in relation to the establishment contractors who undertake to produce a given result for the bank. The petitioners are also persons who undertake to produce the result through contract labour. The petitioners may appoint sub- contractors to do the work. To accede to the petitioners contention that the construction work which Is away from the place where the industry, trade, business of the establishment is carried on is not the work of the establishment is to render the words work of any establishments devoid of ordinary meaning. The construction of the building is the work of the establish- ment. The building is the property of the establishment. Therefore, the construction work is the work of the establishment. That is why a workman is deemed to be employed as contract labour in connection with the work of an establishment. The place where business or rade or industry or manufacture or occupation is carried on is not Synonymous with the, work of the establishment when a contractor employs contract labour in connection with the work of the establishment. The error of the petitioners lies in equating the work of the establishment with the actual place where the business, industry or trade is carried on and the actual work of the business, industry or trade. It is plain that industry, trade, business, manufacture or occupation is to expand. In connection with the expansion of establishment, buildings are constructed. The site chosen for the building is the work site of the establishment. The work site is the place where on completion of construction, the business of the establishment will be carried on. Therefore, the work at the site as understood in the definition is the work of an establishment-. Establishment is understood as including the work site. The construction work which the contractor undertakes is the work of the establishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of definitions of contractor, establishment, principal employer, workman, contract labour; construction produces given result for establishment through contract labour; work site part of establishment; rejects equation of work with main business premises.

holdings.text: The words other work in any establishment in section 10 of the Act are to be construed as ejusdem generis.

anchor.surface_text: The words other work in any establishment in section 10 of the Act are important. The work in the es- tablishment will be apparent from section 10  2  of the Act as incidental or necessary to the industry, trade, business, manufacture or occupation that is carried on in the establishment. The Government before notifying prohibition of contract labour for work which is carried on in the establishment will consider whether the work is of a Perennial nature in that establishment or work is done ordinarily, through regular workmen in that establishment. The words work of an establishment which are used in defining workmen as contract labour being employed in connection with the work of an establishment indicate that the work of the establishment there is not the same as work in the establishment contemplated in section 10 of the Act. The words other work in any establishment in section 10 are to be, construed as ejusdem generis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation limiting 'other work' to same genus as 'process, operation' in s.10(2); distinguishes from 'work of establishment' in definitions.

holdings.text: There is no unreasonableness in the measure.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention on behalf of the petitioners is that the provisions of the Act and the Rules made thereunder are unconstitutional. It is said that the application of the Act in respect of pending work of construction amounts to unreasonable restriction on the right of the contractors under Article 19  1   g . The bill was introduced in 1967. It was passed in 1970, There is no unreasonableness in that it applies to pending contracts. The pendency of contract is not a relevant consideration. The subject-matter of the legislation is not contract. it is contract labour. There is no retrospective operation. There are no materials to show that the petitioners will suffer. The contractors have not shown the contracts to show the rates of work. It is also not known whether the petitioners have clauses in the contract to ask for increase of rates in changed circumstances. That is usual in contracts. The petitioners during the years 1967 to 1970 knew that the legislative measure was going to find place in the statute book. The crucial point is that the interests of the workmen are remedied by the objects of the Act. Those interests are minimum labour welfare. There is no unreasonableness in the measure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No retrospectivity; regulates labour not contracts; workmen welfare paramount; no evidence of hardship; known pending legislation.

holdings.text: The fees prescribed for registration, licence and renewal of licences do not amount to a levy of tax.

anchor.surface_text: The fees prescribed for registration, licence or renewal of licences are said to amount to a tax and are therefore beyond the rule-making powers of the Central and State Governments. The fees prescribed for registration, licence and renewal of licences do not amount to a levy of tax. The Government has to bear expenses for the scheme of registration, licence. The Government gives service in regard to licences and registration. Further there is no arbitrary power or excessive delegation of legislative authority in regard to grant of licence. The Act and the Rules provide ample guideline as to the grant and terms and conditions of licence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fees for services rendered (registration, licensing), not tax; government bears regulatory expenses.

holdings.text: There is no violation of Article 14. The classification is not arbitrary. The legislature has made uniform laws for all contractors.

anchor.surface_text: There is a rational relation between the impugned Act and the object to be achieved and the provision is not in excess of that object. There is no violation of Article 14. The classification is not arbitrary. The legislature has made uniform laws for all contractors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform application to all contractors; rational nexus to welfare object; not arbitrary.

holdings.text: The provision for canteen is not unreasonable. It is not impracticable to have a canteen.

anchor.surface_text: The provision for canteen is not unreasonable. It is not impracticable to have a canteen. A city like Bombay or the construction of road is not an insurmountable feature by itself to hold either that the provision is unreasonable or impracticable. Section 17 of the Act states that in every place where contract labour is required to halt at night in connection with the work of the establishment, there shall be provided a rest room as mentioned therein. Rule 41 of the Central Rules states that where contract labour is likely to continue for three months or more and where contract labour is required to halt at night, rest rooms shall be provided. It is not unreasonable to provide rest room. The contractor will make necessary provision. It will be unreasonable to hold that a labourer will be required to halt at night at the place of work but he will not have any rest room.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Welfare amenities rational and practicable; legislature determines needs; no proof of impossibility; capable even in cities/roads.

holdings.text: The provisions of the Act with regard to forfeiture do not suffer from any constitutional infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act with regard to forfeiture do not suffer from any constitutional infirmity. The rules are not inconsistent with the provisions of the Act. The forfeiture of security is for due performance or as a penalty on the licensee. The order for forfeiture is an administrative penalty. The provisions contained in sections 23 to 26 of the Act indicate that contravention of the provisions regarding employment of contract labour is punishable in Criminal Court. The Licensing Officer under section 14 of the Act is not a Court. Therefore, there is no aspect of double jeopardy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative after show cause opportunity; appealable; rational rate per workman; no double jeopardy (not judicial); for due performance.

holdings.text: Therefore, section 34 of the Act does not amount to excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, section 34 of the Act does not amount to excessive delegation. Section 28 of the Act was challenged as conferring arbitrary and unguided power and, therefore violative of Articles 14 and 19. Section 28 of the Act confers power on the Government to appoint persons as it thinks fit to be the inspectors for the purposes of the Act and such inspector shall have power to enter at all reasonable hours the premises or place where contract labour is employed for the purpose of examining any register or record or notice and examine any person and seize, or take copies of documents mentioned therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to implementation difficulties; no finality or alteration of provisions; distinguishes Jalan Trading (no such vices here).

holdings.text: An intervener cannot raise points which are not canvassed by the petitioners in the pleadings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: s.28 challenge not in petitioners' pleadings.

holdings.text: For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioners is unsound. When the banking company employs the petitioners to construct a building the petitioners are in relation to the establishment contractors who undertake to produce a given result for the bank. The petitioners are also persons who undertake to produce the result through contract labour. The petitioners may appoint sub- contractors to do the work. To accede to the petitioners contention that the construction work which Is away from the place where the industry, trade, business of the establishment is carried on is not the work of the establishment is to render the words work of any establishments devoid of ordinary meaning. The construction of the building is the work of the establish- ment. The building is the property of the establishment. Therefore, the construction work is the work of the establishment. That is why a workman is deemed to be employed as contract labour in connection with the work of an establishment. The place where business or rade or industry or manufacture or occupation is carried on is not Synonymous with the, work of the establishment when a contractor employs contract labour in connection with the work of the establishment. The error of the petitioners lies in equating the work of the establishment with the actual place where the business, industry or trade is carried on and the actual work of the business, industry or trade. It is plain that industry, trade, business, manufacture or occupation is to expand. In connection with the expansion of establishment, buildings are constructed. The site chosen for the building is the work site of the establishment. The work site is the place where on completion of construction, the business of the establishment will be carried on. Therefore, the work at the site as understood in the definition is the work of an establishment-. Establishment is understood as including the work site. The construction work which the contractor undertakes is the work of the establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention on behalf of the petitioners is that the provisions of the Act and the Rules made thereunder are unconstitutional. It is said that the application of the Act in respect of pending work of construction amounts to unreasonable restriction on the right of the contractors under Article 19  1   g . The bill was introduced in 1967. It was passed in 1970, There is no unreasonableness in that it applies to pending contracts. The pendency of contract is not a relevant consideration. The subject-matter of the legislation is not contract. it is contract labour. There is no retrospective operation. There are no materials to show that the petitioners will suffer. The contractors have not shown the contracts to show the rates of work. It is also not known whether the petitioners have clauses in the contract to ask for increase of rates in changed circumstances. That is usual in contracts. The petitioners during the years 1967 to 1970 knew that the legislative measure was going to find place in the statute book. The crucial point is that the interests of the workmen are remedied by the objects of the Act. Those interests are minimum labour welfare. There is no unreasonableness in the measure.
For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed. Parties will pay and bear their own costs.

anchor.surface_text: The fees prescribed for registration, licence or renewal of licences are said to amount to a tax and are therefore beyond the rule-making powers of the Central and State Governments. The fees prescribed for registration, licence and renewal of licences do not amount to a levy of tax. The Government has to bear expenses for the scheme of registration, licence. The Government gives service in regard to licences and registration. Further there is no arbitrary power or excessive delegation of legislative authority in regard to grant of licence. The Act and the Rules provide ample guideline as to the grant and terms and conditions of licence.
For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed. Parties will pay and bear their own costs.

anchor.surface_text: The provision for canteen is not unreasonable. It is not impracticable to have a canteen. A city like Bombay or the construction of road is not an insurmountable feature by itself to hold either that the provision is unreasonable or impracticable. Section 17 of the Act states that in every place where contract labour is required to halt at night in connection with the work of the establishment, there shall be provided a rest room as mentioned therein. Rule 41 of the Central Rules states that where contract labour is likely to continue for three months or more and where contract labour is required to halt at night, rest rooms shall be provided. It is not unreasonable to provide rest room. The contractor will make necessary provision. It will be unreasonable to hold that a labourer will be required to halt at night at the place of work but he will not have any rest room.
For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed. Parties will pay and bear their own costs.

edges.explanation: The holding declaring no constitutional infirmity in forfeiture provisions directly addresses the issue questioning the constitutionality of s14 under Articles 14 and 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act with regard to forfeiture do not suffer from any constitutional infirmity. The rules are not inconsistent with the provisions of the Act. The forfeiture of security is for due performance or as a penalty on the licensee. The order for forfeiture is an administrative penalty. The provisions contained in sections 23 to 26 of the Act indicate that contravention of the provisions regarding employment of contract labour is punishable in Criminal Court. The Licensing Officer under section 14 of the Act is not a Court. Therefore, there is no aspect of double jeopardy.
For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed. Parties will pay and bear their own costs.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, section 34 of the Act does not amount to excessive delegation. Section 28 of the Act was challenged as conferring arbitrary and unguided power and, therefore violative of Articles 14 and 19. Section 28 of the Act confers power on the Government to appoint persons as it thinks fit to be the inspectors for the purposes of the Act and such inspector shall have power to enter at all reasonable hours the premises or place where contract labour is employed for the purpose of examining any register or record or notice and examine any person and seize, or take copies of documents mentioned therein.
For these reasons, the contentions of the petitioners fail. The petitions are dismissed. Parties will pay and bear their own costs.
